Nerangs.ab: u-š aṣ̌əm frāz gīrišn u-š pad vohū kārd abar nihēd u-š pad vahištəm bē brīnišn tā sē tāg pad abestāg bē čīnēd hamē ka ēw tāg apādyāb bē bawēd ā-š wāz abāz gīrišn ka-š sē tāg pad abestāg čīnēd ka harw sē apādyāb bē bawēd ā-š wāz abāz nē gīrišn kar sar hušk...

"He has to grab (the branch) it at aṣ̌əm, to put the knife at vohū, to cut it at vahištəm (and to repeat the process thus) until he cuts three pieces while reciting the abestāg. Every time that a branch is polluted, he has to take again the wāz. When all three become polluted, then he has not to take again the wāz. When the tip is dry..."

va pe aṣ̌əm sar-e šāḫ-e barsom boridan va meqdār-e ēk dāne-ye ǧou va dar afgandan pas vohū barsom-čin bar miyān-e barsom nihādan pas vahištəm tak-i barsom boridan pas astī uštā astī uštā aɱāi tā sar ḫvāndan se šāḫ-e barsom b-in dastur āvāyad čidan pas har čand ke ḫᵛāhand činand hame-rā yek-yek bar āvāyad boridan meqdār-e yek dāne-ye ǧou vaqt šomordan mi-vāyad ke ǧoft ǧoft šomārand dar āḫar yeki ke ṭāq bāšad agar ǧoft bāšad yeki digar čidan pas aivyanghan be-hamin vāǧ bečinand ke aivanghan vāǧ gīrišn nadārad pas be-hamān šāḫ-e barsom āyand ke vāǧ gerefte bāšand vāǧ be-guyand

"At aṣ̌əm he should cut the end of the barsom-twig in the size of a corn of barley and detach it. Then (at) vohū he should put the barsom-čin on the middle of the barsom. Then at vahištəm he should cut one twig of the barsom and then recite astī uštā astī uštā aɱāi upto the end. He should cut in this way (at least) three twigs of the barsom. Then he should cut twig by twig as many twigs as they want to cut. He should cut the end of all branches, one to one, in the size of one corn of barley. When they count, they should count by pairs. Eventually, it must remain a single piece. If they are pairs, then another one should be cut. Afterwards, they cut the aivyanghan with even the same vāǧ. If there is not vāǧ-gīrešn for the aivanghan, then they go to exactly the branch of the barsom at which they has taken the vāǧ and say the vāǧ."

va se aṣ̌em avāyad ḫᵛānd ašem ke miguyad sar-e barsom avāyad dāšt vohi miyān-e barsom kārd mizanad va vahištem bon-e barsom be činad tā se tāk-e barsom čide šavad baʿd az ān har šāḫi be barsom bāšad be čidan va ʿaivyānghan be činad va baʿd az ān bāyad va vāǧ be-guyad va ān šāḫi ke barsom se tāk čide-and be-girand

"He must recite three Aṣ̌əm Vohūs. When he recites aṣ̌em, he must hold the the tip of the barsom. At vohū, they put the knife on the mid of the barsom. At vahištəm, he cuts the tip of barsom until he has cut three twigs of the barsom. Afterwards, he should cut as many braches as needed for the barsom. He cuts the aivyanghan. Afterwards, he must recite the vāǧ and they take the branch from which three barsom-twigs have been cut."

pa aṣ̌em yek ǧou sar-e barsom boridan pa vōhū barsom-cin bar miyān-e barsom nahādan va pa vahištəm tak-i barsam boridan pas astī uštā astī uštā aɱāi hiiat̰ aṣ̌āi vahištāi aṣ̌əm ĪĪĪ aṣ̌əm vōhū goftan va se tā barsam cidan va pas harcand barsam ḫᵛāhand cidan va šomāre kardan cenānke ṭāq bāšad va agar ǧoft bāšad yeki digar cidan va †pas hamān šāḫ ke avval vāǧ gerefte bāšad gereftan

"At aṣ̌em he must cut (the size of) a barley corn at the end of the barsom. At vōhū, he should put the barsom-cin on the middle of the barsom. At vahištəm, he should cut one twig of the barsom. Then he should recite astī uštā astī uštā aɱāi and three aṣ̌əm vohū and cut three pieces of the barsom. Then, he should cut as many barsom-branches as they want, and count then so that they are an even number. If they are odd, he must cut an aditional one. Then he should take the same branch that he took with the first vāǧ."

Quotations.ab: u-š pad aṣ̌əm frāz gīrišn u-š pad vohū kārd abar nihišn u-š pad vahištəm bē brīnišn tā sē tāg pad abestāg bē čīnēd hamē ka ēw tāg apādyāb bē bawēd ā-š wāz abāz gīrišn ka-š sē tāg pad abestāg čīnēd ka harw sē apādyāb bē bawēd ā-š wāz abāz nē gīrišn

"He has to grab (the branch) at aṣ̌əm, to put the knife at vohū, to cut it at vahištəm (and to repeat the process thus) until he cuts three pieces while reciting the abestāg. Every time that a branch is polluted, he has to take again the wāz. When all three become polluted, then he has not to take again the wāz."
